objects.name: Attack Flow
objects.description: Extends STIX 2.1 with features to create Attack Flows.

external_references.description: Source code repository for Attack Flow

objects.name: MITRE Engenuity Center for Threat-Informed Defense
FIN13 Case 1
objects.description: Attack by FIN13 against a Latin American bank
author: name
Mia Sanchez
identity_class
contact_information
msanschez@mitre.org

objects.name: Active Scanning: Vulnerability Scanning
objects.description: The attacker scanned the perimeter of the victim looking for vulnerable webservices.

objects.name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
objects.description: Exploited a vulnerability in the Oracle WebLogic server, and passed malicious content via POST requests to a web page called AsyncResponseServiceHttps, and executed commands

objects.name: Active Scanning
objects.description: Scanned the targeted web server again.

objects.name: IP Address
objects.description: The attacker used IP address 185.193.126.22 to scan the perimeter network and later again to scan the target web server.

objects.name: Server Software Component: Web Shell
objects.description: Uploaded and accessed a webshellÂ

objects.name: CVE-2019-2729
objects.description: Oracle WebLogic Server Deserialization RCE (aka object injection vulnerability) - user-controllable data is deserialized by a website, allowing an attacker to pass harmful data into an application. This vulnerability is exploitable without authentication.

objects.name: Network Service Discovery
objects.description: Attempted to recon the DMZ segment where the infected webserver was operating.

objects.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
objects.description: Uploaded a zip archive of tools for various OS via the webshell onto the compromised web server

objects.name: Zip File of Tools
objects.description: The zip archive contained: BlueAgave (PowerShell HTTP Bind Shell), a Perl version of BlueAgave, PHP webshell, Java Database browser, PortHole (Java Scanner), RawCap (Java packet capture tool), SpinOff SQL Browser, Latchkey (Powersploit script to dump the lsass.exe process)

objects.name: Defense Evasion
objects.description: To avoid detection, the attacker halted activity for about a week

objects.name: Lateral Movement
objects.description: Attacker used a common credential with the Zabbix server to move laterally.

objects.name: Server Software Component: Web shell
objects.description: Implanted a WSO PHP webshell on the Zabbix server.

objects.name: Server Software Component: Webshell
objects.description: Attacker dropped a BlueAgave Perl webshell, configured on port 65510

objects.name: File and Directory Permissions Modification
objects.description: Viewed folders and modified permissions to the "/srv/www/htdocs/gif" folder.

objects.name: System Owner/User Discovery
objects.description: Enumerated the environment by  running "whoami."

objects.name: Credentials from Password Stores
objects.description: Viewed the "/etc/shadow" file on the Zabbix server.
Gained control of the Zabbix server

objects.name: Active Scanning: Scanning IP Blocks
objects.description: Attacker launched massive ping sweeps against private subnets.
Machine responds to the ping sweep

objects.name: Lateral Tool Transfer
objects.description: PortHole used to verify the first 10,000 TCP ports of any machine that responded to the ping sweep
Identified Domain Controller through scan of the Backend DMZ Lan and waited 1 week to attack the AD server

objects.name: Lateral Tool Transfer
objects.description: Transferred additional tools to the Zabbix from the WebLogic Server

objects.name: Transferred Tools
objects.description: Malicious tools found in Zabbix server: 65.txt (perl webshell), chart10.php (webshell), p.txt (Java port scanner), pr64.zip (procdump64), bi.txt (perl bind shell), s0b.j (Jar that queries db), str-isis.txt (jdbc connection/credential info), jtds-1.2.1.jar (likely jdbc deriver), and str-bio.txt (jdbc connection/credential info)

objects.name: Exploitation of Remote Services
objects.description: Attacker moved laterally from the Zabbix server to the Oracle Identity Manager server (in the DMZ)

objects.name: OS Credential Dumping
objects.description: Attacker dumped the sysadmin account related to the IAM service

objects.name: Network Sniffing
objects.description: Sniffed credentials passed by the IAM service to the DMZ servers.

objects.name: RawCap
objects.description: The attacker installed the Java capture tool RawCap to sniff credentials.
Attacker intercepted additional domain and local passwords.

objects.name: Lateral Movement
objects.description: Moved laterally to the Backweb server

objects.name: Steal or Forge Kerberos Tickets: Kerberoasting
objects.description: Attacker used Kerberoasting technique to collect the ticket from system memory and crack offline to obtain credentials.

objects.name: IP Address
objects.description: The attacker used external IP addresses to access Backweb server

objects.name: Server Software Component: Webshell
objects.description: Decoded PowerShell payload results in a similar PowerShell HTTP Bindshell that listens on port 65512

objects.name: Active Scanning: Scanning IP Blocks
objects.description: Scanned internal subnets looking for additional servers
Identified a cluster of RSA SecurID servers

objects.name: Brute Force
objects.description: Attacker attempted to access the RSA servers by leveraging service accounts previously stolen through executing dictionary-based access attempts

objects.name: Data from Local System
objects.description: The attackers dumped the database containing the SecurID token serials with the corresponding end-user accounts

objects.name: Multi-Factor Authentication Interception
objects.description: Attacker harvested token serials from the database and collected daily token transactions in clear text stored inside a service account folder, where the storage procedure was scripted
Attacker activated the token recovery procedure for bank users

objects.name: Valid Accounts
objects.description: Attacker logged into the bank users' accounts

objects.name: Fraud
objects.description: Attacker transferred money from the online banking system

objects.name: FIN13
objects.description: FIN13 is a financially-motivated actor primarily focusing on Latin America with activity stretching back to early 2016. FIN13 has a history of highly localized targeting against the financial, retail, and hospitality industries.
goals: financially-motivated and targeting Latin American organizations in financial, retail, and hospitality industries

objects.name: FIN13 Case 1
objects.description: This attack began in March 2021 and targeted a Latin American bank. After exploiting the system, the attackers committed fraud between Sept-Oct 2021, impacting hundreds of accounts and stealing a significant amount of money.

objects.name: Oracle Web Server
objects.description: Exposed server running a vulnerable version of WebLogic
Discovered a vulnerable webserver - Oracle Weblogic
Discovered a DMZ monitoring server, Auth server, and DMZ DNS server

objects.name: web server
objects.description: infected web server is used to stage malicious executables for the attacker
Attacker access the webshell again

objects.name: Zabbix server
objects.description: DMZ monitoring service

objects.name: Firewall Misconfiguration
objects.description: misconfigured firewall allowed the attacker to put the webshell accessible from the Internet by publishing it on a public IP belonging to the victim IPv4 public address space on port TCP/80

objects.name: Indicator Removal on Host: Clear Linux or Mac System Logs
objects.description: Attackers viewed contents in the /var/log/apache2/ folder and removed entries of the access logs. Confidence: 70
Attacker checked for file 65510 in /dev/shm

objects.name: PortHole
objects.description: Java-based port scanner

objects.name: CWE-309
objects.description: Use of Password System for Primary Authentication - the Zabbis root password was also the password for the Oracle Identity Manager server

objects.name: Remote Services: SSH
objects.description: Attacker used SSH to access the Oracle IAM server administrative UI

objects.name: Data from Local System
objects.description: Attacker dumped the IAM local database of accounts allowing them to find domain accounts

objects.name: Indicator Removal on Host: File Deletion
objects.description: Attacker deleted RawCap output files and the RawCap tool

objects.name: Backweb server
objects.description: an internal web portal including domain accounts
Attacker logged on to the Backweb server

objects.name: Lateral Tool Transfer
objects.description: Attacker copied pr64.zip to the Backweb server

objects.name: pr64.zip
objects.description: renamed procdump

objects.name: Valid Accounts: Local Accounts
objects.description: Attacker accessed the Backweb server using customasp local user account

objects.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell
objects.description: Attacker created a service and initialized it with an obfuscated PowerShell payload

objects.name: Lateral Tool Transfer
objects.description: Attacker left several files in "Windows\Temp" directory, such as the Java scanner

objects.name: Gather Victim Network Information
objects.description: Attacker enumerated databases in the same network segment as the RSA servers
Attacker switched tactics to access SecurID server

objects.name: Active Scanning
objects.description: Attacker scanned for MS-SQL servers

objects.name: Lateral Tool Transfer
objects.description: Attacker moved several tools to the Backweb server

objects.name: Added tools
objects.description: s0b.j, str-isis.txt, jtds-1.2.1.jar, str-bio.txt

objects.name: s0b.j
objects.description: Accepts base64 encoded SQL queries and uses a configuration file that contains the connection string and credentials of the target databased server
Using s0b.j, attacker accessed multiple databases, including a database storing the SecurID token serials with corresponding end-user accounts

objects.name: Remote Services: Remote Desktop Protocol
objects.description: Attacker accessed the Backweb server again multiple times using RDP and the sqlservice and sqlinstall accounts

objects.name: .weblog.jsp
objects.description: a jspRAT that can manipulate files and directories and run arbitrary Windows commands

objects.content: The report does not specify how or when the attackers got the common credential, but I assume it is with one of the tools uploaded in the zip file.Â

objects.name: 65.txt
objects.description: BlueAgave Perl webshell placed on the Zabbix Server

objects.content: Several txt files were found in the unallocated address space of the Zabbix machine that were outputs from these scanning attempts
showed the failed SSH connection attempts, indicating a dictionary-based access attempts
